trans-unit.source: Migrating ACS Namespaces to Google OpenID Connect
trans-unit.target: Migrating ACS Namespaces to Google OpenID Connect

trans-unit.source: This topic is for owners of Access Control Service (ACS) 2.0 namespaces that currently use Google as an identity provider.
trans-unit.target: This topic is for owners of Access Control Service (ACS) 2.0 namespaces that currently use Google as an identity provider.

trans-unit.source: ACS provides this capability using Google’s OpenID 2.0 implementation.
trans-unit.target: ACS provides this capability using Google’s OpenID 2.0 implementation.

trans-unit.source: Google plans to discontinue OpenID 2.0 support by April 20, 2015.
trans-unit.target: Google plans to discontinue OpenID 2.0 support by April 20, 2015.

trans-unit.source: ACS namespaces will continue to work with Google’s OpenID 2.0 implementation until June 1, 2015, by which time you must complete migration of these namespaces to use Google’s OpenID Connect implementation or users will no longer be able to sign in to your application with a Google account.
trans-unit.target: ACS namespaces will continue to work with Google’s OpenID 2.0 implementation until June 1, 2015, by which time you must complete migration of these namespaces to use Google’s OpenID Connect implementation or users will no longer be able to sign in to your application with a Google account.

trans-unit.source: Migrating your ACS namespaces to OpenID Connect will not cause application downtime.
trans-unit.target: Migrating your ACS namespaces to OpenID Connect will not cause application downtime.

trans-unit.source: With one exception (see note below), this migration is possible without changing application code.
trans-unit.target: With one exception (see note below), this migration is possible without changing application code.

trans-unit.source: After migrating your ACS namespaces to use OpenID Connect, you will need to migrate your users’ identifiers in your backend to OpenID Connect identifiers.
trans-unit.target: After migrating your ACS namespaces to use OpenID Connect, you will need to migrate your users’ identifiers in your backend to OpenID Connect identifiers.

trans-unit.source: This migration must be completed by January 1, 2017.
trans-unit.target: This migration must be completed by January 1, 2017.

trans-unit.source: It will require code changes in your backend.
trans-unit.target: It will require code changes in your backend.

trans-unit.source: See the important note below for details about both phases of migration.
trans-unit.target: See the important note below for details about both phases of migration.

trans-unit.source: Note the following important dates and complete the actions required by each date to ensure that your ACS namespaces that use Google as an identity provider continue to work:
trans-unit.target: Note the following important dates and complete the actions required by each date to ensure that your ACS namespaces that use Google as an identity provider continue to work:

trans-unit.source: <embeddedLabel>June 1, 2015</embeddedLabel> - ACS namespaces will stop working with Google’s OpenID 2.0 implementation.
trans-unit.target: <embeddedLabel>June 1, 2015</embeddedLabel> - ACS namespaces will stop working with Google’s OpenID 2.0 implementation.

trans-unit.source: You must complete ACS namespace migration to use Google OpenID Connect by this date.
trans-unit.target: You must complete ACS namespace migration to use Google OpenID Connect by this date.

trans-unit.source: Before this date, you can roll back to OpenID 2.0 if you encounter problems during migration.
trans-unit.target: Before this date, you can roll back to OpenID 2.0 if you encounter problems during migration.

trans-unit.source: For namespaces that have not been migrated by this date, users will no longer be able to sign in with a Google account and will be presented with a page that indicates that OpenID 2.0 for Google accounts has gone away.
trans-unit.target: For namespaces that have not been migrated by this date, users will no longer be able to sign in with a Google account and will be presented with a page that indicates that OpenID 2.0 for Google accounts has gone away.

trans-unit.source: To restore sign-in capability with Google accounts, you will need to migrate the namespace.
trans-unit.target: To restore sign-in capability with Google accounts, you will need to migrate the namespace.

trans-unit.source: In most cases, no application code changes should be required.
trans-unit.target: In most cases, no application code changes should be required.

trans-unit.source: If you have the “<embeddedLabel>passthrough all claims</embeddedLabel>” rule for Google as an identity provider in a rule group associated with your application, though, you may need to make code changes.
trans-unit.target: If you have the “<embeddedLabel>passthrough all claims</embeddedLabel>” rule for Google as an identity provider in a rule group associated with your application, though, you may need to make code changes.

trans-unit.source: This is because, upon migration, a new claim type (<embeddedLabel>Subject</embeddedLabel>) becomes available to ACS from Google, and you might have to make code changes to ensure that your application can handle the presence of the new claim type gracefully.
trans-unit.target: This is because, upon migration, a new claim type (<embeddedLabel>Subject</embeddedLabel>) becomes available to ACS from Google, and you might have to make code changes to ensure that your application can handle the presence of the new claim type gracefully.

trans-unit.source: To successfully complete migration, there won’t be any need to process the new claim type in your application.
trans-unit.target: To successfully complete migration, there won’t be any need to process the new claim type in your application.

trans-unit.source: <embeddedLabel>Jan 1, 2017</embeddedLabel> – Google’s OpenID 2.0 and OpenID Connect implementations use different identifiers to uniquely identify Google users.
trans-unit.target: <embeddedLabel>Jan 1, 2017</embeddedLabel> – Google’s OpenID 2.0 and OpenID Connect implementations use different identifiers to uniquely identify Google users.

trans-unit.source: When you migrate your ACS namespace, ACS makes two identifiers, both the current OpenID 2.0 identifier and the new OpenID Connect identifier, available to your application.
trans-unit.target: When you migrate your ACS namespace, ACS makes two identifiers, both the current OpenID 2.0 identifier and the new OpenID Connect identifier, available to your application.

trans-unit.source: You must switch your users’ identifiers in your backend system to OpenID Connect identifiers by this date, and start using only OpenID Connect identifiers going forward.
trans-unit.target: You must switch your users’ identifiers in your backend system to OpenID Connect identifiers by this date, and start using only OpenID Connect identifiers going forward.

trans-unit.source: This requires application code changes.
trans-unit.target: This requires application code changes.

trans-unit.source: You can post questions about migration on <externalLink><linkText>Stack Overflow</linkText><linkUri>http://stackoverflow.com/</linkUri></externalLink> and tag them with ‘acs-google’.
trans-unit.target: You can post questions about migration on <externalLink><linkText>Stack Overflow</linkText><linkUri>http://stackoverflow.com/</linkUri></externalLink> and tag them with ‘acs-google’.

trans-unit.source: We will respond as quickly as possible.
trans-unit.target: We will respond as quickly as possible.

trans-unit.source: For more information about Google’s plans, see their <externalLink><linkText>OpenID 2.0 Migration Guide</linkText><linkUri>https://developers.google.com/accounts/docs/OpenID</linkUri></externalLink>.
trans-unit.target: For more information about Google’s plans, see their <externalLink><linkText>OpenID 2.0 Migration Guide</linkText><linkUri>https://developers.google.com/accounts/docs/OpenID</linkUri></externalLink>.

trans-unit.source: Migration Checklist
trans-unit.target: Migration Checklist

trans-unit.source: The following table contains a checklist that summarizes the steps required to migrate your ACS namespace to use Google’s OpenID Connect implementation:
trans-unit.target: The following table contains a checklist that summarizes the steps required to migrate your ACS namespace to use Google’s OpenID Connect implementation:

trans-unit.source: Step
trans-unit.target: Step

trans-unit.source: Description
trans-unit.target: Description

trans-unit.source: Must be Completed by
trans-unit.target: Must be Completed by

trans-unit.source: Create a Google+ application at the <embeddedLabel>Google Developers Console</embeddedLabel>.
trans-unit.target: Create a Google+ application at the <embeddedLabel>Google Developers Console</embeddedLabel>.

trans-unit.source: June 1, 2015
trans-unit.target: June 1, 2015

trans-unit.source: If you have the “<embeddedLabel>passthrough all claims</embeddedLabel>” rule for Google as an identity provider in a rule group associated with your application, test your application to ensure that it is migration-ready; otherwise, this step is optional.
trans-unit.target: If you have the “<embeddedLabel>passthrough all claims</embeddedLabel>” rule for Google as an identity provider in a rule group associated with your application, test your application to ensure that it is migration-ready; otherwise, this step is optional.

trans-unit.source: June 1, 2015
trans-unit.target: June 1, 2015

trans-unit.source: Use the <embeddedLabel>ACS Management Portal</embeddedLabel> to switch your ACS namespace to use Google’s OpenID Connect implementation by supplying it with your Google+ application’s parameters (Client ID and Client secret).
trans-unit.target: Use the <embeddedLabel>ACS Management Portal</embeddedLabel> to switch your ACS namespace to use Google’s OpenID Connect implementation by supplying it with your Google+ application’s parameters (Client ID and Client secret).

trans-unit.source: If you encounter problems with your migration, roll back to OpenID 2.0 is possible until June 1, 2015.
trans-unit.target: If you encounter problems with your migration, roll back to OpenID 2.0 is possible until June 1, 2015.

trans-unit.source: June 1, 2015
trans-unit.target: June 1, 2015

trans-unit.source: Migrate your users’ identifiers in your backend system from the current Google OpenID 2.0 identifiers to the new Google OpenID Connect identifiers.
trans-unit.target: Migrate your users’ identifiers in your backend system from the current Google OpenID 2.0 identifiers to the new Google OpenID Connect identifiers.

trans-unit.source: This requires code changes.
trans-unit.target: This requires code changes.

trans-unit.source: Migration walkthrough
trans-unit.target: Migration walkthrough

trans-unit.source: To migrate your ACS namespace to use Google’s OpenID Connect implementation, complete the following steps:
trans-unit.target: To migrate your ACS namespace to use Google’s OpenID Connect implementation, complete the following steps:

trans-unit.source: Create a Google+ application
trans-unit.target: Create a Google+ application

trans-unit.source: For detailed instructions on how to do this, see the <link xlink:href="#BKMK_HowToCreateAGooglePlusApplication" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">How to: Create a Google+ application</link> section.
trans-unit.target: For detailed instructions on how to do this, see the <link xlink:href="#BKMK_HowToCreateAGooglePlusApplication" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">How to: Create a Google+ application</link> section.

trans-unit.source: Ensure that your application is migration-ready
trans-unit.target: Ensure that your application is migration-ready

trans-unit.source: If you have the “<embeddedLabel>passthrough all claims</embeddedLabel>” rule for Google as an identity provider in a rule group associated with your application, follow the instructions in the <link xlink:href="abed9a15-8466-4c3a-80e0-8fa24a3ea0f7#BKMK_HowToEnsureAnAcsApplicationsMigrationReadiness" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">How to: Ensure an ACS application’s migration readiness</link> section to test your application for migration readiness.
trans-unit.target: If you have the “<embeddedLabel>passthrough all claims</embeddedLabel>” rule for Google as an identity provider in a rule group associated with your application, follow the instructions in the <link xlink:href="abed9a15-8466-4c3a-80e0-8fa24a3ea0f7#BKMK_HowToEnsureAnAcsApplicationsMigrationReadiness" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">How to: Ensure an ACS application’s migration readiness</link> section to test your application for migration readiness.

trans-unit.source: This is because upon migration a new claim type (<embeddedLabel>Subject</embeddedLabel>) becomes available to ACS from Google.
trans-unit.target: This is because upon migration a new claim type (<embeddedLabel>Subject</embeddedLabel>) becomes available to ACS from Google.

trans-unit.source: A “<embeddedLabel>passthrough all claims</embeddedLabel>” rule is a rule where <legacyItalic>Input claim type</legacyItalic> and <embeddedLabel> Input claim value</embeddedLabel> are set to <embeddedLabel>Any</embeddedLabel> and <embeddedLabel>Output claim type</embeddedLabel> and <embeddedLabel>Output claim value</embeddedLabel> are set to <embeddedLabel>Pass through first input claim type</embeddedLabel> and <embeddedLabel>Pass through input claim value</embeddedLabel> respectively.
trans-unit.target: A “<embeddedLabel>passthrough all claims</embeddedLabel>” rule is a rule where <legacyItalic>Input claim type</legacyItalic> and <embeddedLabel> Input claim value</embeddedLabel> are set to <embeddedLabel>Any</embeddedLabel> and <embeddedLabel>Output claim type</embeddedLabel> and <embeddedLabel>Output claim value</embeddedLabel> are set to <embeddedLabel>Pass through first input claim type</embeddedLabel> and <embeddedLabel>Pass through input claim value</embeddedLabel> respectively.

trans-unit.source: The rule is listed on the <embeddedLabel>ACS Management Portal</embeddedLabel> as shown below, with the <embeddedLabel>Output Claim</embeddedLabel> column set to <embeddedLabel>Passthrough</embeddedLabel>.
trans-unit.target: The rule is listed on the <embeddedLabel>ACS Management Portal</embeddedLabel> as shown below, with the <embeddedLabel>Output Claim</embeddedLabel> column set to <embeddedLabel>Passthrough</embeddedLabel>.

trans-unit.source: If you have previously generated rules or added rules manually for Google as an identity provider in a rule group associated with your application, you can skip this step.
trans-unit.target: If you have previously generated rules or added rules manually for Google as an identity provider in a rule group associated with your application, you can skip this step.

trans-unit.source: This is because, in these cases, upon migration the new <embeddedLabel>Subject</embeddedLabel> claim type is not sent to the application.
trans-unit.target: This is because, in these cases, upon migration the new <embeddedLabel>Subject</embeddedLabel> claim type is not sent to the application.

trans-unit.source: To learn more about these options, see <link xlink:href="7ef0ec98-9fa8-4671-bcf7-630ebb06ec7e" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">Rule Groups and Rules</link>.
trans-unit.target: To learn more about these options, see <link xlink:href="7ef0ec98-9fa8-4671-bcf7-630ebb06ec7e" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">Rule Groups and Rules</link>.

trans-unit.source: Switch the ACS namespace to use Google’s OpenID Connect implementation
trans-unit.target: Switch the ACS namespace to use Google’s OpenID Connect implementation

trans-unit.source: Go to the <externalLink><linkText>Microsoft Azure Management Portal</linkText> <linkUri>https://manage.windowsazure.com</linkUri></externalLink>, sign in, and click <embeddedLabel>Active Directory</embeddedLabel>.
trans-unit.target: Go to the <externalLink><linkText>Microsoft Azure Management Portal</linkText> <linkUri>https://manage.windowsazure.com</linkUri></externalLink>, sign in, and click <embeddedLabel>Active Directory</embeddedLabel>.

trans-unit.source: Select the ACS namespace that needs to be migrated and click <embeddedLabel>Manage</embeddedLabel> to launch the <embeddedLabel>ACS Management Portal</embeddedLabel>.
trans-unit.target: Select the ACS namespace that needs to be migrated and click <embeddedLabel>Manage</embeddedLabel> to launch the <embeddedLabel>ACS Management Portal</embeddedLabel>.

trans-unit.source: On the <embeddedLabel>ACS Management Portal</embeddedLabel>, click <embeddedLabel>Identity Providers</embeddedLabel> in the tree on the left-hand side or click the <embeddedLabel>Identity Providers</embeddedLabel> link under the <embeddedLabel>Getting Started</embeddedLabel> section.
trans-unit.target: On the <embeddedLabel>ACS Management Portal</embeddedLabel>, click <embeddedLabel>Identity Providers</embeddedLabel> in the tree on the left-hand side or click the <embeddedLabel>Identity Providers</embeddedLabel> link under the <embeddedLabel>Getting Started</embeddedLabel> section.

trans-unit.source: Click <embeddedLabel>Google</embeddedLabel>.
trans-unit.target: Click <embeddedLabel>Google</embeddedLabel>.

trans-unit.source: In the <embeddedLabel>Edit Google Identity Provider</embeddedLabel> page, check <embeddedLabel>Use OpenID Connect</embeddedLabel>.
trans-unit.target: In the <embeddedLabel>Edit Google Identity Provider</embeddedLabel> page, check <embeddedLabel>Use OpenID Connect</embeddedLabel>.

trans-unit.source: In the <embeddedLabel>Client ID</embeddedLabel> and <embeddedLabel>Client secret</embeddedLabel> fields (now enabled), copy in the corresponding values from your Google+ application.
trans-unit.target: In the <embeddedLabel>Client ID</embeddedLabel> and <embeddedLabel>Client secret</embeddedLabel> fields (now enabled), copy in the corresponding values from your Google+ application.

trans-unit.source: At this point if you click <embeddedLabel>Save</embeddedLabel>, all Google identity provider requests from your ACS namespace will automatically use Google’s OpenID Connect implementation.
trans-unit.target: At this point if you click <embeddedLabel>Save</embeddedLabel>, all Google identity provider requests from your ACS namespace will automatically use Google’s OpenID Connect implementation.

trans-unit.source: If you need to roll back, you can uncheck <embeddedLabel>Use OpenID Connect</embeddedLabel>.
trans-unit.target: If you need to roll back, you can uncheck <embeddedLabel>Use OpenID Connect</embeddedLabel>.

trans-unit.source: The Client ID and Client secret stay saved and can be re-used later on.
trans-unit.target: The Client ID and Client secret stay saved and can be re-used later on.

trans-unit.source: Click <embeddedLabel>Save</embeddedLabel>.
trans-unit.target: Click <embeddedLabel>Save</embeddedLabel>.

trans-unit.source: Try signing in with a Google ID to ensure that the switch to using OpenID Connect was successful.
trans-unit.target: Try signing in with a Google ID to ensure that the switch to using OpenID Connect was successful.

trans-unit.source: If you have trouble signing in, go back to the <embeddedLabel>Edit Google Identity Provider</embeddedLabel> page and un-check <embeddedLabel>Use OpenID Connect</embeddedLabel> to roll back to OpenID 2.0.
trans-unit.target: If you have trouble signing in, go back to the <embeddedLabel>Edit Google Identity Provider</embeddedLabel> page and un-check <embeddedLabel>Use OpenID Connect</embeddedLabel> to roll back to OpenID 2.0.

trans-unit.source: After you roll back, check that the <embeddedLabel>Client ID</embeddedLabel> and <embeddedLabel>Secret</embeddedLabel> that you copied from the <embeddedLabel>Google Developer Console</embeddedLabel> are entered correctly for your namespace; for example, check for typos.
trans-unit.target: After you roll back, check that the <embeddedLabel>Client ID</embeddedLabel> and <embeddedLabel>Secret</embeddedLabel> that you copied from the <embeddedLabel>Google Developer Console</embeddedLabel> are entered correctly for your namespace; for example, check for typos.

trans-unit.source: Migrate your users’ identifiers in your backend system from Open ID 2.0 to OpenID Connect
trans-unit.target: Migrate your users’ identifiers in your backend system from Open ID 2.0 to OpenID Connect

trans-unit.source: You must migrate your users’ identifiers in your backend system from the existing Google Open ID 2.0 identifiers to the new Google OpenID Connect identifiers before Jan 1, 2017.
trans-unit.target: You must migrate your users’ identifiers in your backend system from the existing Google Open ID 2.0 identifiers to the new Google OpenID Connect identifiers before Jan 1, 2017.

trans-unit.source: This step requires code changes.
trans-unit.target: This step requires code changes.

trans-unit.source: For more information, see <link xlink:href="abed9a15-8466-4c3a-80e0-8fa24a3ea0f7#BKMK_HowToMigrateOpenID20ToOpenIDConnect" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">How to: Migrate your users’ existing Open ID 2.0 identifiers to new OpenID Connect user identifiers</link>
trans-unit.target: For more information, see <link xlink:href="abed9a15-8466-4c3a-80e0-8fa24a3ea0f7#BKMK_HowToMigrateOpenID20ToOpenIDConnect" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">How to: Migrate your users’ existing Open ID 2.0 identifiers to new OpenID Connect user identifiers</link>

trans-unit.source: How to: Create a Google+ application
trans-unit.target: How to: Create a Google+ application

trans-unit.source: You will need a Google account to perform the following steps; if you don’t have one, you can get one at <externalLink><linkText>https://accounts.google.com/SignUp</linkText><linkUri>https://accounts.google.com/SignUp</linkUri></externalLink>.
trans-unit.target: You will need a Google account to perform the following steps; if you don’t have one, you can get one at <externalLink><linkText>https://accounts.google.com/SignUp</linkText><linkUri>https://accounts.google.com/SignUp</linkUri></externalLink>.

trans-unit.source: In a browser window, navigate to the <externalLink><linkText>Google Developers Console</linkText><linkUri>https://console.developers.google.com/</linkUri></externalLink> and sign-in with your Google account credentials.
trans-unit.target: In a browser window, navigate to the <externalLink><linkText>Google Developers Console</linkText><linkUri>https://console.developers.google.com/</linkUri></externalLink> and sign-in with your Google account credentials.

trans-unit.source: Click <embeddedLabel>Create Project</embeddedLabel>, and enter a <embeddedLabel>Project name</embeddedLabel> and <embeddedLabel>Project ID</embeddedLabel>.
trans-unit.target: Click <embeddedLabel>Create Project</embeddedLabel>, and enter a <embeddedLabel>Project name</embeddedLabel> and <embeddedLabel>Project ID</embeddedLabel>.

trans-unit.source: Check the <embeddedLabel>Terms of Service</embeddedLabel> checkbox.
trans-unit.target: Check the <embeddedLabel>Terms of Service</embeddedLabel> checkbox.

trans-unit.source: Then click <embeddedLabel>Create</embeddedLabel>.
trans-unit.target: Then click <embeddedLabel>Create</embeddedLabel>.

trans-unit.source: This registers the application with Google.
trans-unit.target: This registers the application with Google.

trans-unit.source: Click <embeddedLabel>APIs & auth</embeddedLabel> on the left pane.
trans-unit.target: Click <embeddedLabel>APIs & auth</embeddedLabel> on the left pane.

trans-unit.source: And then click <embeddedLabel>Credentials</embeddedLabel>.
trans-unit.target: And then click <embeddedLabel>Credentials</embeddedLabel>.

trans-unit.source: Under <embeddedLabel>OAuth</embeddedLabel>, click <embeddedLabel>Create new Client ID</embeddedLabel>.Select <embeddedLabel>Web Application</embeddedLabel> and click <embeddedLabel>Configure consent screen</embeddedLabel>.
trans-unit.target: Under <embeddedLabel>OAuth</embeddedLabel>, click <embeddedLabel>Create new Client ID</embeddedLabel>.Select <embeddedLabel>Web Application</embeddedLabel> and click <embeddedLabel>Configure consent screen</embeddedLabel>.

trans-unit.source: Provide a <embeddedLabel>Product Name</embeddedLabel> and click <embeddedLabel>Save</embeddedLabel>.
trans-unit.target: Provide a <embeddedLabel>Product Name</embeddedLabel> and click <embeddedLabel>Save</embeddedLabel>.

trans-unit.source: Click <embeddedLabel>APIs & auth</embeddedLabel> on the left pane.
trans-unit.target: Click <embeddedLabel>APIs & auth</embeddedLabel> on the left pane.

trans-unit.source: And then click <embeddedLabel>APIs</embeddedLabel>.
trans-unit.target: And then click <embeddedLabel>APIs</embeddedLabel>.

trans-unit.source: Under <embeddedLabel>Browse APIs</embeddedLabel>, search and find <embeddedLabel>Google+ API</embeddedLabel>.
trans-unit.target: Under <embeddedLabel>Browse APIs</embeddedLabel>, search and find <embeddedLabel>Google+ API</embeddedLabel>.

trans-unit.source: Turn the <embeddedLabel>Status</embeddedLabel> to <embeddedLabel>ON</embeddedLabel>.
trans-unit.target: Turn the <embeddedLabel>Status</embeddedLabel> to <embeddedLabel>ON</embeddedLabel>.

trans-unit.source: In the <embeddedLabel>Create Client ID</embeddedLabel> dialog, select <embeddedLabel>Web Application</embeddedLabel> as the <embeddedLabel>Application Type</embeddedLabel>.
trans-unit.target: In the <embeddedLabel>Create Client ID</embeddedLabel> dialog, select <embeddedLabel>Web Application</embeddedLabel> as the <embeddedLabel>Application Type</embeddedLabel>.

trans-unit.source: In the <embeddedLabel>Authorized Javascript Origins</embeddedLabel> field, specify the fully qualified domain name (FQDN) URL of your namespace, including the leading “HTTPS://” and the trailing port number; for example, https://contoso.accesscontrol.windows.net:443.
trans-unit.target: In the <embeddedLabel>Authorized Javascript Origins</embeddedLabel> field, specify the fully qualified domain name (FQDN) URL of your namespace, including the leading “HTTPS://” and the trailing port number; for example, https://contoso.accesscontrol.windows.net:443.

trans-unit.source: In the <embeddedLabel>Authorized Redirect URIs</embeddedLabel> field, specify a URI which contains the fully qualified domain name (FQDN) URL of your namespace, including the leading “HTTPS://” and the trailing port number, followed by “/v2/openid”; for example, https://contoso.accesscontrol.windows.net:443/v2/openid.
trans-unit.target: In the <embeddedLabel>Authorized Redirect URIs</embeddedLabel> field, specify a URI which contains the fully qualified domain name (FQDN) URL of your namespace, including the leading “HTTPS://” and the trailing port number, followed by “/v2/openid”; for example, https://contoso.accesscontrol.windows.net:443/v2/openid.

trans-unit.source: Click <embeddedLabel>Create Client ID</embeddedLabel>.
trans-unit.target: Click <embeddedLabel>Create Client ID</embeddedLabel>.

trans-unit.source: Note down the values of <embeddedLabel>Client ID</embeddedLabel> and <embeddedLabel>Client secret</embeddedLabel> from the <embeddedLabel>Client ID for web application</embeddedLabel> page.
trans-unit.target: Note down the values of <embeddedLabel>Client ID</embeddedLabel> and <embeddedLabel>Client secret</embeddedLabel> from the <embeddedLabel>Client ID for web application</embeddedLabel> page.

trans-unit.source: You will need them to configure Google’s OpenID Connect implementation on the <embeddedLabel>ACS Management Portal</embeddedLabel>.
trans-unit.target: You will need them to configure Google’s OpenID Connect implementation on the <embeddedLabel>ACS Management Portal</embeddedLabel>.

trans-unit.source: <embeddedLabel>Client Secret</embeddedLabel> is an important security credential.
trans-unit.target: <embeddedLabel>Client Secret</embeddedLabel> is an important security credential.

trans-unit.source: Keep it secret.
trans-unit.target: Keep it secret.

trans-unit.source: How to: Migrate your users’ existing Open ID 2.0 identifiers to new OpenID Connect user identifiers
trans-unit.target: How to: Migrate your users’ existing Open ID 2.0 identifiers to new OpenID Connect user identifiers

trans-unit.source: After you have successfully migrated your ACS namespace to use Google’s OpenID Connect implementation, you have until Jan 1, 2017 (per Google’s <externalLink><linkText>OpenID 2.0 Migration Guide</linkText><linkUri>https://developers.google.com/accounts/docs/OpenID</linkUri></externalLink>) to migrate your users’ identifiers in your backend system from the current OpenID 2.0 identifiers to the new OpenID Connect identifiers.
trans-unit.target: After you have successfully migrated your ACS namespace to use Google’s OpenID Connect implementation, you have until Jan 1, 2017 (per Google’s <externalLink><linkText>OpenID 2.0 Migration Guide</linkText><linkUri>https://developers.google.com/accounts/docs/OpenID</linkUri></externalLink>) to migrate your users’ identifiers in your backend system from the current OpenID 2.0 identifiers to the new OpenID Connect identifiers.

trans-unit.source: The following table shows claim types that become available to ACS from Google once the ACS namespace has been migrated to use Google’s OpenID Connect implementation:
trans-unit.target: The following table shows claim types that become available to ACS from Google once the ACS namespace has been migrated to use Google’s OpenID Connect implementation:

trans-unit.source: Claim Type
trans-unit.target: Claim Type

trans-unit.source: URI
trans-unit.target: URI

trans-unit.source: Description
trans-unit.target: Description

trans-unit.source: Protocol Availability
trans-unit.target: Protocol Availability

trans-unit.source: Name Identifier
trans-unit.target: Name Identifier

trans-unit.source: http://schemas.xmlsoap.org/ws/2005/05/identity/claims/nameidentifier
trans-unit.target: http://schemas.xmlsoap.org/ws/2005/05/identity/claims/nameidentifier

trans-unit.source: A unique identifier for the user account, provided by Google.
trans-unit.target: A unique identifier for the user account, provided by Google.

trans-unit.source: This is the (existing) OpenID 2.0 identifier.
trans-unit.target: This is the (existing) OpenID 2.0 identifier.

trans-unit.source: OpenID 2.0, OpenID Connect
trans-unit.target: OpenID 2.0, OpenID Connect

trans-unit.source: Subject
trans-unit.target: Subject

trans-unit.source: http://schemas.microsoft.com/identity/claims/subject
trans-unit.target: http://schemas.microsoft.com/identity/claims/subject

trans-unit.source: A unique identifier for the user account, provided by Google.
trans-unit.target: A unique identifier for the user account, provided by Google.

trans-unit.source: This is the (new) OpenID Connect identifier.
trans-unit.target: This is the (new) OpenID Connect identifier.

trans-unit.source: OpenID Connect
trans-unit.target: OpenID Connect

trans-unit.source: Name
trans-unit.target: Name

trans-unit.source: http://schemas.xmlsoap.org/ws/2005/05/identity/claims/name
trans-unit.target: http://schemas.xmlsoap.org/ws/2005/05/identity/claims/name

trans-unit.source: The display name for the user account, provided by Google.
trans-unit.target: The display name for the user account, provided by Google.

trans-unit.source: OpenID 2.0, OpenID Connect
trans-unit.target: OpenID 2.0, OpenID Connect

trans-unit.source: (see note below)
trans-unit.target: (see note below)

trans-unit.source: Email Address
trans-unit.target: Email Address

trans-unit.source: http://schemas.xmlsoap.org/ws/2005/05/identity/claims/emailaddress
trans-unit.target: http://schemas.xmlsoap.org/ws/2005/05/identity/claims/emailaddress

trans-unit.source: The email address for the user account, provided by Google
trans-unit.target: The email address for the user account, provided by Google

trans-unit.source: OpenID 2.0, OpenID Connect
trans-unit.target: OpenID 2.0, OpenID Connect

trans-unit.source: Identity Provider
trans-unit.target: Identity Provider

trans-unit.source: http://schemas.microsoft.com/accesscontrolservice/2010/07/claims/IdentityProvider
trans-unit.target: http://schemas.microsoft.com/accesscontrolservice/2010/07/claims/IdentityProvider

trans-unit.source: A claim provided by ACS that tells the relying party application that the user authenticated using the default Google identity provider.
trans-unit.target: A claim provided by ACS that tells the relying party application that the user authenticated using the default Google identity provider.

trans-unit.source: The value of this claim is visible in the ACS Management Portal via the Realm field in the Edit Identity Provider page.
trans-unit.target: The value of this claim is visible in the ACS Management Portal via the Realm field in the Edit Identity Provider page.

trans-unit.source: OpenID 2.0, OpenID Connect
trans-unit.target: OpenID 2.0, OpenID Connect

trans-unit.source: For a Google user who doesn’t have a (registered) Google+ profile, the value of the <embeddedLabel>Name</embeddedLabel> claim type is the same as the value of the <embeddedLabel>Email address</embeddedLabel> claim type in OpenID Connect.
trans-unit.target: For a Google user who doesn’t have a (registered) Google+ profile, the value of the <embeddedLabel>Name</embeddedLabel> claim type is the same as the value of the <embeddedLabel>Email address</embeddedLabel> claim type in OpenID Connect.

trans-unit.source: The <embeddedLabel>Name Identifier</embeddedLabel> and <embeddedLabel>Subject</embeddedLabel> claim types can be used to track and switch existing users’ unique identifiers in your backend by mapping (old) OpenID 2.0 identifiers to (new) OpenID Connect identifiers.
trans-unit.target: The <embeddedLabel>Name Identifier</embeddedLabel> and <embeddedLabel>Subject</embeddedLabel> claim types can be used to track and switch existing users’ unique identifiers in your backend by mapping (old) OpenID 2.0 identifiers to (new) OpenID Connect identifiers.

trans-unit.source: If you have the “<embeddedLabel>passthrough all claims</embeddedLabel>” rule for Google as an identity provider in a rule group associated your application, your application will automatically start receiving the <embeddedLabel>Subject</embeddedLabel> claim type.
trans-unit.target: If you have the “<embeddedLabel>passthrough all claims</embeddedLabel>” rule for Google as an identity provider in a rule group associated your application, your application will automatically start receiving the <embeddedLabel>Subject</embeddedLabel> claim type.

trans-unit.source: If you have previously generated rules or added rules manually for Google as an identity provider in a rule group associated with your application, you will need to add the <embeddedLabel>Subject</embeddedLabel> claim type manually.
trans-unit.target: If you have previously generated rules or added rules manually for Google as an identity provider in a rule group associated with your application, you will need to add the <embeddedLabel>Subject</embeddedLabel> claim type manually.

trans-unit.source: For more information on how to do this, see <link xlink:href="7ef0ec98-9fa8-4671-bcf7-630ebb06ec7e" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">Rule Groups and Rules</link>.
trans-unit.target: For more information on how to do this, see <link xlink:href="7ef0ec98-9fa8-4671-bcf7-630ebb06ec7e" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">Rule Groups and Rules</link>.

trans-unit.source: For example, if you had previously generated rules for Google as an identity provider in a rule group and then add the new <embeddedLabel>Subject</embeddedLabel> claim type (as shown above), you will see the following.
trans-unit.target: For example, if you had previously generated rules for Google as an identity provider in a rule group and then add the new <embeddedLabel>Subject</embeddedLabel> claim type (as shown above), you will see the following.

trans-unit.source: The application using this rule group will receive the <embeddedLabel>Subject</embeddedLabel> claim type, along with other claim types.
trans-unit.target: The application using this rule group will receive the <embeddedLabel>Subject</embeddedLabel> claim type, along with other claim types.

trans-unit.source: After Jan 1, 2017, when Google discontinues its support for identifier mapping, ACS will populate both the <embeddedLabel>NameIdentifier</embeddedLabel> and <embeddedLabel>Subject</embeddedLabel> claim types with the same OpenID Connect user identifier.
trans-unit.target: After Jan 1, 2017, when Google discontinues its support for identifier mapping, ACS will populate both the <embeddedLabel>NameIdentifier</embeddedLabel> and <embeddedLabel>Subject</embeddedLabel> claim types with the same OpenID Connect user identifier.

trans-unit.source: How to: Ensure an ACS application’s migration readiness
trans-unit.target: How to: Ensure an ACS application’s migration readiness

trans-unit.source: With one exception, migrating your ACS namespace to use Google’s OpenID Connect implementation is possible without changing application code.
trans-unit.target: With one exception, migrating your ACS namespace to use Google’s OpenID Connect implementation is possible without changing application code.

trans-unit.source: The exception case is if you have the “<embeddedLabel>passthrough all claims</embeddedLabel>” rule for Google as an identity provider in a rule group associated with your application.
trans-unit.target: The exception case is if you have the “<embeddedLabel>passthrough all claims</embeddedLabel>” rule for Google as an identity provider in a rule group associated with your application.

trans-unit.source: This is because, in this case, upon migration a new claim type (<embeddedLabel>Subject</embeddedLabel>) is automatically sent to the application.
trans-unit.target: This is because, in this case, upon migration a new claim type (<embeddedLabel>Subject</embeddedLabel>) is automatically sent to the application.

trans-unit.source: This section outlines the recommended change and test procedure that you can follow to ensure that every application that will be impacted by migration is ready to handle the new claim type.
trans-unit.target: This section outlines the recommended change and test procedure that you can follow to ensure that every application that will be impacted by migration is ready to handle the new claim type.

trans-unit.source: For the purposes of this How To, assume that you are the owner of an ACS namespace called <embeddedLabel>ns-contoso</embeddedLabel> and that your application in production is called <embeddedLabel>ProdContosoApp</embeddedLabel>.
trans-unit.target: For the purposes of this How To, assume that you are the owner of an ACS namespace called <embeddedLabel>ns-contoso</embeddedLabel> and that your application in production is called <embeddedLabel>ProdContosoApp</embeddedLabel>.

trans-unit.source: Also assume that this application uses Google as an identity provider and has “<embeddedLabel>passthrough all claims</embeddedLabel>” rule enabled for Google.
trans-unit.target: Also assume that this application uses Google as an identity provider and has “<embeddedLabel>passthrough all claims</embeddedLabel>” rule enabled for Google.

trans-unit.source: Setup
trans-unit.target: Setup

trans-unit.source: To get started, go to the <externalLink><linkText>Microsoft Azure Management Portal</linkText> <linkUri>https://manage.windowsazure.com</linkUri></externalLink>, sign in, and then click <embeddedLabel>Active Directory</embeddedLabel>.
trans-unit.target: To get started, go to the <externalLink><linkText>Microsoft Azure Management Portal</linkText> <linkUri>https://manage.windowsazure.com</linkUri></externalLink>, sign in, and then click <embeddedLabel>Active Directory</embeddedLabel>.

trans-unit.source: Select the ACS namespace (<embeddedLabel>ns-contoso</embeddedLabel>), and then click <embeddedLabel>Manage</embeddedLabel> to launch the <embeddedLabel>ACS Management Portal</embeddedLabel>.
trans-unit.target: Select the ACS namespace (<embeddedLabel>ns-contoso</embeddedLabel>), and then click <embeddedLabel>Manage</embeddedLabel> to launch the <embeddedLabel>ACS Management Portal</embeddedLabel>.

trans-unit.source: On the <embeddedLabel>ACS Management Portal</embeddedLabel>, click <embeddedLabel>Relying Party Applications</embeddedLabel> in the tree on the left-hand side or click the <embeddedLabel>Relying Party Applications</embeddedLabel> link under the <embeddedLabel>Getting Started</embeddedLabel> section.
trans-unit.target: On the <embeddedLabel>ACS Management Portal</embeddedLabel>, click <embeddedLabel>Relying Party Applications</embeddedLabel> in the tree on the left-hand side or click the <embeddedLabel>Relying Party Applications</embeddedLabel> link under the <embeddedLabel>Getting Started</embeddedLabel> section.

trans-unit.source: Then click on your production application (<embeddedLabel>ProdContosoApp</embeddedLabel>).
trans-unit.target: Then click on your production application (<embeddedLabel>ProdContosoApp</embeddedLabel>).

trans-unit.source: Note down properties of <embeddedLabel>ProdContosoApp</embeddedLabel>, you will need these later.
trans-unit.target: Note down properties of <embeddedLabel>ProdContosoApp</embeddedLabel>, you will need these later.

trans-unit.source: Click <embeddedLabel>Default Rule Group for ProdContosoApp</embeddedLabel> under <embeddedLabel>Rule groups</embeddedLabel> to verify that it has the “<embeddedLabel>passthrough all claims</embeddedLabel>” rule enabled for Google.
trans-unit.target: Click <embeddedLabel>Default Rule Group for ProdContosoApp</embeddedLabel> under <embeddedLabel>Rule groups</embeddedLabel> to verify that it has the “<embeddedLabel>passthrough all claims</embeddedLabel>” rule enabled for Google.

trans-unit.source: Step 1: Setup a test instance of your application in your production ACS namespace
trans-unit.target: Step 1: Setup a test instance of your application in your production ACS namespace

trans-unit.source: Set up a test instance of your application, <embeddedLabel>TestContosoApp</embeddedLabel>, on a different root URI; for example, https://contoso-test.com:7777/.
trans-unit.target: Set up a test instance of your application, <embeddedLabel>TestContosoApp</embeddedLabel>, on a different root URI; for example, https://contoso-test.com:7777/.

trans-unit.source: You will have to register it as a Relying Party Application (<link xlink:href="16708a9e-e1f1-4ad5-bed2-a49ccabc42b9" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">Relying Party Applications</link>) in the ns-contoso namespace.
trans-unit.target: You will have to register it as a Relying Party Application (<link xlink:href="16708a9e-e1f1-4ad5-bed2-a49ccabc42b9" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">Relying Party Applications</link>) in the ns-contoso namespace.

trans-unit.source: On the <embeddedLabel>ACS Management Portal</embeddedLabel>, click <embeddedLabel>Relying Party Applications</embeddedLabel> in the tree on the left-hand side or click the <embeddedLabel>Relying Party Applications</embeddedLabel> link under the <embeddedLabel>Getting Started</embeddedLabel> section.
trans-unit.target: On the <embeddedLabel>ACS Management Portal</embeddedLabel>, click <embeddedLabel>Relying Party Applications</embeddedLabel> in the tree on the left-hand side or click the <embeddedLabel>Relying Party Applications</embeddedLabel> link under the <embeddedLabel>Getting Started</embeddedLabel> section.

trans-unit.source: Then click <embeddedLabel>Add</embeddedLabel> on the <embeddedLabel>Relying Party Applications</embeddedLabel> page.
trans-unit.target: Then click <embeddedLabel>Add</embeddedLabel> on the <embeddedLabel>Relying Party Applications</embeddedLabel> page.

trans-unit.source: On the <embeddedLabel>Add Relying Partying Application</embeddedLabel> page, do the following:
trans-unit.target: On the <embeddedLabel>Add Relying Partying Application</embeddedLabel> page, do the following:

trans-unit.source: In <embeddedLabel>Name</embeddedLabel>, type the name of the test application.
trans-unit.target: In <embeddedLabel>Name</embeddedLabel>, type the name of the test application.

trans-unit.source: Here it is <embeddedLabel>TestContosoApp</embeddedLabel>.
trans-unit.target: Here it is <embeddedLabel>TestContosoApp</embeddedLabel>.

trans-unit.source: In <embeddedLabel>Mode</embeddedLabel>, select <embeddedLabel>Enter settings manually</embeddedLabel>.
trans-unit.target: In <embeddedLabel>Mode</embeddedLabel>, select <embeddedLabel>Enter settings manually</embeddedLabel>.

trans-unit.source: In <embeddedLabel>Realm</embeddedLabel>, type in the test application’s URI.
trans-unit.target: In <embeddedLabel>Realm</embeddedLabel>, type in the test application’s URI.

trans-unit.source: Here it is https://contoso-test.com:7777/.
trans-unit.target: Here it is https://contoso-test.com:7777/.

trans-unit.source: For the purposes of this How to, you can leave <embeddedLabel>Error URL (optional)</embeddedLabel> blank.
trans-unit.target: For the purposes of this How to, you can leave <embeddedLabel>Error URL (optional)</embeddedLabel> blank.

trans-unit.source: For the <embeddedLabel>Token format</embeddedLabel>, <embeddedLabel>Token encryption policy</embeddedLabel>, and <embeddedLabel>Token lifetime (secs)</embeddedLabel> properties and the <embeddedLabel>Token Signing Settings</embeddedLabel> section, use the same values that you used for <embeddedLabel>ProdContosoApp</embeddedLabel>.
trans-unit.target: For the <embeddedLabel>Token format</embeddedLabel>, <embeddedLabel>Token encryption policy</embeddedLabel>, and <embeddedLabel>Token lifetime (secs)</embeddedLabel> properties and the <embeddedLabel>Token Signing Settings</embeddedLabel> section, use the same values that you used for <embeddedLabel>ProdContosoApp</embeddedLabel>.

trans-unit.source: Make sure that you have selected <embeddedLabel>Google</embeddedLabel> as an <embeddedLabel>Identity Provider</embeddedLabel>.
trans-unit.target: Make sure that you have selected <embeddedLabel>Google</embeddedLabel> as an <embeddedLabel>Identity Provider</embeddedLabel>.

trans-unit.source: Under <embeddedLabel>Rule Groups</embeddedLabel>, select <embeddedLabel>Create new rule group</embeddedLabel>.
trans-unit.target: Under <embeddedLabel>Rule Groups</embeddedLabel>, select <embeddedLabel>Create new rule group</embeddedLabel>.

trans-unit.source: Click <embeddedLabel>Save</embeddedLabel> at the bottom of the page.
trans-unit.target: Click <embeddedLabel>Save</embeddedLabel> at the bottom of the page.

trans-unit.source: Step 2: Create a Rule Group that simulates the format of the ACS token that the application will receive once the namespace has been migrated to use Google’s OpenID Connect implementation
trans-unit.target: Step 2: Create a Rule Group that simulates the format of the ACS token that the application will receive once the namespace has been migrated to use Google’s OpenID Connect implementation

trans-unit.source: On the <embeddedLabel>ACS Management Portal</embeddedLabel>, click <embeddedLabel>Rule Groups</embeddedLabel> in the tree on the left-hand side or click the <embeddedLabel>Rules Group</embeddedLabel> link under the <embeddedLabel>Getting Started</embeddedLabel> section.
trans-unit.target: On the <embeddedLabel>ACS Management Portal</embeddedLabel>, click <embeddedLabel>Rule Groups</embeddedLabel> in the tree on the left-hand side or click the <embeddedLabel>Rules Group</embeddedLabel> link under the <embeddedLabel>Getting Started</embeddedLabel> section.

trans-unit.source: Then click <embeddedLabel>Add</embeddedLabel> on the <embeddedLabel>Rule Groups</embeddedLabel> page.
trans-unit.target: Then click <embeddedLabel>Add</embeddedLabel> on the <embeddedLabel>Rule Groups</embeddedLabel> page.

trans-unit.source: On the <embeddedLabel>Add Rule Group</embeddedLabel> page, provide a name for the new rule group, say <embeddedLabel>ManualGoogleRuleGroup</embeddedLabel>.
trans-unit.target: On the <embeddedLabel>Add Rule Group</embeddedLabel> page, provide a name for the new rule group, say <embeddedLabel>ManualGoogleRuleGroup</embeddedLabel>.

trans-unit.source: Click Save.
trans-unit.target: Click Save.

trans-unit.source: On the <embeddedLabel>Edit Rule Group</embeddedLabel> page, click the <embeddedLabel>Add</embeddedLabel> link.
trans-unit.target: On the <embeddedLabel>Edit Rule Group</embeddedLabel> page, click the <embeddedLabel>Add</embeddedLabel> link.

trans-unit.source: In the <embeddedLabel>Add Claim Rule</embeddedLabel> page, make sure that you have the following values in place and click <embeddedLabel>Save</embeddedLabel>.
trans-unit.target: In the <embeddedLabel>Add Claim Rule</embeddedLabel> page, make sure that you have the following values in place and click <embeddedLabel>Save</embeddedLabel>.

trans-unit.source: This generates a “<embeddedLabel>passthrough all claims</embeddedLabel>” rule for Google.
trans-unit.target: This generates a “<embeddedLabel>passthrough all claims</embeddedLabel>” rule for Google.

trans-unit.source: <embeddedLabel>If</embeddedLabel> section:
trans-unit.target: <embeddedLabel>If</embeddedLabel> section:

trans-unit.source: <embeddedLabel>Identity Provider</embeddedLabel> is <embeddedLabel>Google</embeddedLabel>.
trans-unit.target: <embeddedLabel>Identity Provider</embeddedLabel> is <embeddedLabel>Google</embeddedLabel>.

trans-unit.source: <embeddedLabel>Input claim type</embeddedLabel> selection is <embeddedLabel>Any</embeddedLabel>.
trans-unit.target: <embeddedLabel>Input claim type</embeddedLabel> selection is <embeddedLabel>Any</embeddedLabel>.

trans-unit.source: <embeddedLabel>Input claim value</embeddedLabel> is <embeddedLabel>Any</embeddedLabel>.
trans-unit.target: <embeddedLabel>Input claim value</embeddedLabel> is <embeddedLabel>Any</embeddedLabel>.

trans-unit.source: <embeddedLabel>Then</embeddedLabel> section:
trans-unit.target: <embeddedLabel>Then</embeddedLabel> section:

trans-unit.source: <embeddedLabel>Output claim type</embeddedLabel> is <embeddedLabel>Pass through first claim type</embeddedLabel>.
trans-unit.target: <embeddedLabel>Output claim type</embeddedLabel> is <embeddedLabel>Pass through first claim type</embeddedLabel>.

trans-unit.source: <embeddedLabel>Output claim value</embeddedLabel> is <embeddedLabel>Pass through first input claim value</embeddedLabel>.
trans-unit.target: <embeddedLabel>Output claim value</embeddedLabel> is <embeddedLabel>Pass through first input claim value</embeddedLabel>.

trans-unit.source: <embeddedLabel>Rule information</embeddedLabel> section:
trans-unit.target: <embeddedLabel>Rule information</embeddedLabel> section:

trans-unit.source: Leave the <embeddedLabel>Description (optional)</embeddedLabel> field blank.
trans-unit.target: Leave the <embeddedLabel>Description (optional)</embeddedLabel> field blank.

trans-unit.source: On the <embeddedLabel>Edit Rule Group</embeddedLabel> page, click the <embeddedLabel>Add</embeddedLabel> link again.
trans-unit.target: On the <embeddedLabel>Edit Rule Group</embeddedLabel> page, click the <embeddedLabel>Add</embeddedLabel> link again.

trans-unit.source: On the <embeddedLabel>Add Claim Rule</embeddedLabel> page, make sure that you have the following values in place and click Save.
trans-unit.target: On the <embeddedLabel>Add Claim Rule</embeddedLabel> page, make sure that you have the following values in place and click Save.

trans-unit.source: This generates a “static” claim rule for Google that simulates addition of a new claim type, <embeddedLabel>Subject</embeddedLabel>, which is the new user OpenID Connect identifier that Google sends the application upon migration.
trans-unit.target: This generates a “static” claim rule for Google that simulates addition of a new claim type, <embeddedLabel>Subject</embeddedLabel>, which is the new user OpenID Connect identifier that Google sends the application upon migration.

trans-unit.source: <embeddedLabel>If</embeddedLabel> section:
trans-unit.target: <embeddedLabel>If</embeddedLabel> section:

trans-unit.source: <embeddedLabel>Identity Provider</embeddedLabel> is <embeddedLabel>Google</embeddedLabel>.
trans-unit.target: <embeddedLabel>Identity Provider</embeddedLabel> is <embeddedLabel>Google</embeddedLabel>.

trans-unit.source: <embeddedLabel>Input claim type</embeddedLabel> selection is <embeddedLabel>Any</embeddedLabel>.
trans-unit.target: <embeddedLabel>Input claim type</embeddedLabel> selection is <embeddedLabel>Any</embeddedLabel>.

trans-unit.source: <embeddedLabel>Input claim value</embeddedLabel> is <embeddedLabel>Any</embeddedLabel>.
trans-unit.target: <embeddedLabel>Input claim value</embeddedLabel> is <embeddedLabel>Any</embeddedLabel>.

trans-unit.source: <embeddedLabel>Then</embeddedLabel> section:
trans-unit.target: <embeddedLabel>Then</embeddedLabel> section:

trans-unit.source: <embeddedLabel>Output claim type</embeddedLabel> is <embeddedLabel>Enter type</embeddedLabel>.
trans-unit.target: <embeddedLabel>Output claim type</embeddedLabel> is <embeddedLabel>Enter type</embeddedLabel>.

trans-unit.source: In the field, type <userInput>http://schemas.microsoft.com/identity/claims/subject</userInput>.
trans-unit.target: In the field, type <userInput>http://schemas.microsoft.com/identity/claims/subject</userInput>.

trans-unit.source: <embeddedLabel>Output claim value</embeddedLabel> is <embeddedLabel>Enter value</embeddedLabel>.
trans-unit.target: <embeddedLabel>Output claim value</embeddedLabel> is <embeddedLabel>Enter value</embeddedLabel>.

trans-unit.source: In the field, type <userInput>123456</userInput>.
trans-unit.target: In the field, type <userInput>123456</userInput>.

trans-unit.source: <embeddedLabel>Rule information</embeddedLabel> section:
trans-unit.target: <embeddedLabel>Rule information</embeddedLabel> section:

trans-unit.source: Leave the <embeddedLabel>Description (optional)</embeddedLabel> field blank.
trans-unit.target: Leave the <embeddedLabel>Description (optional)</embeddedLabel> field blank.

trans-unit.source: Click <embeddedLabel>Save</embeddedLabel> on the <embeddedLabel>Edit Rule Group</embeddedLabel> page.
trans-unit.target: Click <embeddedLabel>Save</embeddedLabel> on the <embeddedLabel>Edit Rule Group</embeddedLabel> page.

trans-unit.source: Step 3: Associate the new Rule Group with the test instance of the application
trans-unit.target: Step 3: Associate the new Rule Group with the test instance of the application

trans-unit.source: On the <embeddedLabel>ACS Management Portal</embeddedLabel>, click <embeddedLabel>Relying Party Applications</embeddedLabel> in the tree on the left-hand side or click the <embeddedLabel>Relying Party Applications</embeddedLabel> link under the <embeddedLabel>Getting Started</embeddedLabel> section.
trans-unit.target: On the <embeddedLabel>ACS Management Portal</embeddedLabel>, click <embeddedLabel>Relying Party Applications</embeddedLabel> in the tree on the left-hand side or click the <embeddedLabel>Relying Party Applications</embeddedLabel> link under the <embeddedLabel>Getting Started</embeddedLabel> section.

trans-unit.source: Then click <embeddedLabel>TestContosoApp</embeddedLabel> on the <embeddedLabel>Relying Party Applications</embeddedLabel> page.
trans-unit.target: Then click <embeddedLabel>TestContosoApp</embeddedLabel> on the <embeddedLabel>Relying Party Applications</embeddedLabel> page.

trans-unit.source: On the <embeddedLabel>Edit Relying Party</embeddedLabel> page, select <embeddedLabel>ManualGoogleRuleGroup</embeddedLabel> in the <embeddedLabel>Authentication Settings</embeddedLabel> section and click <embeddedLabel>Save</embeddedLabel>.
trans-unit.target: On the <embeddedLabel>Edit Relying Party</embeddedLabel> page, select <embeddedLabel>ManualGoogleRuleGroup</embeddedLabel> in the <embeddedLabel>Authentication Settings</embeddedLabel> section and click <embeddedLabel>Save</embeddedLabel>.

trans-unit.source: At this point, all Google sign-in requests to your test applications will include the new claim type.
trans-unit.target: At this point, all Google sign-in requests to your test applications will include the new claim type.

trans-unit.source: Step 4: Test to ensure that your application can handle the addition of the Subject claim type
trans-unit.target: Step 4: Test to ensure that your application can handle the addition of the Subject claim type

trans-unit.source: Test your application to ensure that it can handle the presence of the new claim type (<embeddedLabel>Subject</embeddedLabel>) gracefully.
trans-unit.target: Test your application to ensure that it can handle the presence of the new claim type (<embeddedLabel>Subject</embeddedLabel>) gracefully.

trans-unit.source: Normally, a well written application should be robust to new claim types being added to the token.
trans-unit.target: Normally, a well written application should be robust to new claim types being added to the token.

trans-unit.source: Find and fix any issues.
trans-unit.target: Find and fix any issues.

trans-unit.source: Optionally, you can also follow the <link xlink:href="#BKMK_HowToMigrateOpenID20ToOpenIDConnect" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">How to: Migrate your users’ existing Open ID 2.0 identifiers to new OpenID Connect user identifiers</link> section to do user identifier mapping.
trans-unit.target: Optionally, you can also follow the <link xlink:href="#BKMK_HowToMigrateOpenID20ToOpenIDConnect" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">How to: Migrate your users’ existing Open ID 2.0 identifiers to new OpenID Connect user identifiers</link> section to do user identifier mapping.

trans-unit.source: Step 5: Migrate your production environment
trans-unit.target: Step 5: Migrate your production environment

trans-unit.source: Re-build and deploy your production application (<embeddedLabel>ProdContosoApp</embeddedLabel>).
trans-unit.target: Re-build and deploy your production application (<embeddedLabel>ProdContosoApp</embeddedLabel>).

trans-unit.source: Migrate the namespace (<embeddedLabel>ns-contoso</embeddedLabel>) to use Google’s OpenID Connect implementation by following the steps in the <link xlink:href="#BKMK_MiigrationWalkthrough" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">Migration walkthrough</link>.
trans-unit.target: Migrate the namespace (<embeddedLabel>ns-contoso</embeddedLabel>) to use Google’s OpenID Connect implementation by following the steps in the <link xlink:href="#BKMK_MiigrationWalkthrough" xmlns:xlink="http://www.w3.org/1999/xlink">Migration walkthrough</link>.

trans-unit.source: Verify that <embeddedLabel>ProdContosoApp</embeddedLabel> works as expected.
trans-unit.target: Verify that <embeddedLabel>ProdContosoApp</embeddedLabel> works as expected.
